questions.text: What is not a feature of myasthenia gravis among the following? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Absent deep tendon reflexes.

 

Myasthenia gravis is an autoimmune neuromuscular disorder characterized by weakness and fatiguability of skeletal muscles. There is decrease in number of available acetylcholine receptors at neuromuscular junction due to an antibody mediated autoimmune attack.

 

  • Visual problems, including drooping eyelids (ptosis) and double vision (diplopia)
  • Muscle weakness and fatigue may vary rapidly in intensity over days or even hours and worsen as muscles are used (early fatigue)
  • Facial muscle involvement causing a mask-like appearance; a smile may appear more like a snarl
  • Trouble swallowing or pronouncing words
  • Weakness of the neck or limbs
  • Weakness increases during repeated use or late in the day and may improve following rest or sleep.
  • Deep tendon reflexes preserved.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Muscle fatigue: This is a defining symptom of MG, characterized by increased muscle weakness with continued activity.

 

Option C. Normal pupillary reflex: MG primarily affects voluntary muscles and typically does not impact the autonomic functions, including pupillary reflexes which remain normal.

 

Option D. Ptosis: Ptosis, or drooping eyelids, is one of the common features of MG due to muscle weakness affecting the muscles that control eyelid elevation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Deep tendon reflexes are preserved in myasthenia gravis despite significant muscle weakness and fatigability, distinguishing it from other neuromuscular disorders that might also lead to reflex abnormalities.

questions.text: A chronic alcoholic patient is diagnosed with gouty arthritis. Mark the correct biochemical changes which will be seen in this patient? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Increased urate and lactate levels

 

This patient with chronic alcoholism and gouty arthritis will most likely have elevated levels of lactate and urate.

 

The oxidation of ethanol to acetate by alcohol dehydrogenase is accompanied by the reduction of NAD+ to NADH. This results in a high concentration of NADH, leading to an increased NADH/NAD+ ratio (Hence ruled out Option A).

 

 

Due to this, the following metabolic reactions which require NAD+ are inhibited:

  1. Glycolysis
  2. Citric acid cycle (ketogenesis favoured)
  3. Pyruvate dehydrogenase
  4. Fatty acid oxidation

 

This decreased fatty acid oxidation leads to increased esterification and production of triacylglycerol, which causes fatty liver.

In addition to this, there is an increase in two reactions:

  • Pyruvate to lactate
  • Oxaloacetate to malate

 

Increased lactate leads to hyper-lactic-acidemia, which leads to increased renal reabsorption of urate and decreased excretion of uric acid. This results in aggravation of gout.

 

Alcoholics are deficient in thiamine which inhibits pyruvate dehydrogenase and these all leads to lactic acidosis.

 

A decrease in pyruvate and oxaloacetate levels, which are substrates for gluconeogenesis, leads to a decrease in blood glucose levels, causing symptoms of agitation, impaired judgement.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Decreased NADH/NAD+ ratio: This is incorrect as the NADH/NAD+ ratio is actually increased due to the metabolism of ethanol.

 

Option B: Increased urea and urate levels are not specifically associated with alcoholism and gouty arthritis. But urate levels may be increased due to gout, urea levels are not directly related to the condition.

 

Option D: Increased levels of alkaline phosphatase can be seen in alcohol-induced hepatitis due to intrahepatic cholestasis but is not directly related to gouty arthritis in a chronic alcoholic patient. Therefore, this option is less relevant compared to increased rate and lactate levels.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which of the following is not a marker for gastrointestinal stromal tumor?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) NRG-1

Gastrointestinal stromal tumors (GISTs) are mesenchymal tumors that commonly present with gastrointestinal bleeding. They are characterized by mutations that lead to the overactivity of tyrosine kinase. The most common mutation associated with GISTs is in the CKIT gene, which leads to the activation of the KIT receptor tyrosine kinase.

 

NRG-1 (Neuregulin 1):

 

NRG-1 is a gene that is part of the epidermal growth factor receptor family. It is not associated with GISTs. Instead, NRG-1 is implicated in the pathogenesis of mental health disorders, such as schizophrenia. Therefore, it is not used as a marker for GISTs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. KIT: KIT mutations are the most common genetic alterations found in GISTs and are critical for the diagnosis and treatment of these tumors.

 

Option B. PDGFR: Mutations in the PDGFR gene occur in a subset of GISTs and play a role similar to KIT mutations in tumor development.

 

Option C. SDH: SDH mutations are linked to Carney-Stratakis syndrome and are significant markers in a subset of GISTs. These mutations lead to defects in cellular respiration and are associated with the development of GISTs and paragangliomas.

 

Educational Objective:

 

NRG-1 is not a marker for gastrointestinal stromal tumors. The primary markers for GISTs include KIT, PDGFR, and SDH mutations.

questions.text: Which of the following is connected to the structure marked as A in the image below?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Striate cortex

 

Explanation:

 

  • The structure marked A in the above image is the splenium of the corpus callosum and it is connected to the striate cortex.
  • The striate cortex, also known as the primary visual cortex or V1, is involved in early visual processing, such as processing basic features of visual stimuli like edges, orientation, and motion. It does have connections to the splenium of the corpus callosum, especially for the transfer of visual information between the hemispheres. This connection allows the brain to process visual information from both eyes and integrate it into a cohesive visual experience.
  • The splenium of the corpus callosum primarily connects various regions of the cerebral hemispheres, facilitating communication between the left and right cerebral hemispheres.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Orbital Cortex: The orbital cortex is involved in various aspects of emotional processing and decision-making. It is not directly connected to the splenium of the corpus callosum.

 

Option B. Hippocampus: The hippocampus is a crucial structure for memory formation and spatial navigation. While it has connections to other parts of the brain, its primary connection to the corpus callosum is through the more anterior parts, not the splenium.

 

Option D. Optic Chiasma: The optic chiasma is not directly connected to the splenium of the corpus callosum. It is a structure located at the base of the brain where some of the optic nerve fibers from each eye cross over to the opposite side of the brain. This crossover allows for the integration of visual input from both eyes, but it occurs before the information reaches the corpus callosum.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The corpus callosum is divided into four parts: 
    • The rostrum is continuous with the lamina terminalis and connects the orbital surfaces of the frontal lobes.
    • The genu is the bend of the anterior corpus callosum and the forceps minor is a tract that projects fibres from the genu to connect the medial and lateral surfaces of the frontal lobes.
    • The body forms the long central section and its fibres pass through the corona radiata to reach the surface of the hemispheres. 
    • The splenium tapers away at the posterior section, with the forceps major projecting fibres from the splenium to connect the two occipital lobes. Striate cortex (visual area) is located in occupital lobe.
  • The hippocampus is not connected directly to the splenium, but situated inferior to the splenium.

choices.text: Raised JVP with normal waveform

questions.text: A patient presents to you with an irregularly irregular pulse of 120/minute and a pulse deficit of 20. Which of the following would be the JVP finding? (Neet pg 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Absent a wave

 

The patient presents with an irregularly irregular pulse, which is highly suggestive of atrial fibrillation (AF). Atrial fibrillation is characterized by the absence of coordinated atrial contractions, leading to an irregularly irregular ventricular response. This irregularity can be confirmed by a pulse deficit, where the heart rate (as measured by auscultation) is higher than the pulse rate (as felt at the periphery).

 

In atrial fibrillation, the chaotic atrial activity results in the absence of effective atrial contraction. This leads to the absence of a wave in the jugular venous pulse (JVP), as a wave is generated by atrial contraction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Absent p wave: While it is true that atrial fibrillation is characterized by the absence of P waves on the ECG, the question specifically asks about the JVP finding, not the ECG finding.

 

Option C. Cannon a wave: Cannon a waves are typically seen in conditions where there is atrioventricular dissociation, such as complete heart block. They are not associated with atrial fibrillation.

 

Option D. Raised JVP with normal waveform: Raised JVP can occur in various conditions, but the presence of a normal waveform would not be consistent with atrial fibrillation, where the a wave is absent.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In atrial fibrillation, the jugular venous pulse (JVP) typically shows an absent a wave due to the lack of coordinated atrial contraction.

questions.text: Among the options provided, which protozoan parasite is found within Kupffer cells? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Leishmania donovani

 

  • Kupffer cells are macrophages of Liver.
  • Amastigote form of Leishmania donovani is engulfed by macrophages monocytes, and other reticuloendothelial cells → LD-body
  • LD bodies seen in peripheral smear of a patient with Kala azar

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Toxoplasma: In the human host, the parasites form tissue cysts, most commonly in skeletal muscle, myocardium, brain, and eyes

 

Option C. Babesia’s life cycle doesn’t involve liver. Sporozoites directly enter RBCs.

 

Option D. Plasmodium vivax: In the pre-erythrocytic stage, plasmodium sporozoites invade hepatocytes, where they undergo development into merozoites. Subsequently, these merozoites infiltrate red blood cells (RBCs).

 

Educational Objective:

 

The amastigote form of Leishmania donovani, also known as LD bodies, is found within macrophages, including Kupffer cells in the liver, during infection.

choices.text: Complete blood counts
Random blood sugar

questions.text: A patient arrives at the emergency department with altered mental status. Which of the following tests should not be performed initially? (AIIMS NOV 2016)
questions.solution:
Answer. C. Lumbar puncture

 

Explanation:

 

Lumbar puncture is performed less frequently for coma diagnosis due to the effectiveness of neuroimaging in excluding intracerebral and extensive subarachnoid hemorrhage. For patients with an altered level of consciousness, it is recommended that an imaging study, such as a CT scan, be performed prior to a lumbar puncture to exclude a large intracranial mass lesion and prevent herniation.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Complete blood counts: This test is useful to identify potential infections, anemia, or other hematological issues that could contribute to altered sensorium.

 

Option B. Random blood sugar: Measuring blood glucose levels is crucial, as hypo- or hyperglycemia can significantly affect mental status.

 

Option D. Non-contrast CT head: A non-contrast CT scan is a quick and effective imaging study to rule out intracranial abnormalities such as hemorrhage, masses, or signs of increased intracranial pressure, which are critical to assess in a patient with altered sensorium.

 

Educational Objectives

 

Before performing a lumbar puncture in a patient with altered sensorium, it is essential to conduct imaging studies like a CT scan to exclude the presence of a large intracranial mass lesion and prevent herniation.

questions.text: Which of the following fibres reach the Purkinje cell directly?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Inferior olivary nucleus

 

The fibres of inferior olivary nucleus (climbing fibres) reach the purkinje cell directly.

 

The inferior olivary nucleus is a key part of the cerebellar circuitry and is responsible for providing input to the Purkinje cells via the climbing fibers. These fibers make direct synaptic connections with Purkinje cells and are involved in the modulation of motor learning, control, and coordination. The inferior olivary nucleus receives a wide range of inputs from other areas of the brain, including the spinal cord and sensory systems, and is thought to play an important role in the integration of sensory and motor information during movement.

 

Excitatory and inhibitory fibres –

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Raphe nucleus: Primarily associated with serotonin production, influencing many brain functions including mood and sleep, but does not directly connect to Purkinje cells.

 

Option C. Vestibular nucleus: Sends information to the cerebellum about head position and movement via mossy fibers, not directly to Purkinje cells.

 

Option D. Locus coeruleus: Provides widespread noradrenergic projections that influence arousal and attentiveness, not directly targeting Purkinje cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Climbing fibers from the inferior olivary nucleus directly synapse onto Purkinje cells in the cerebellum, playing a pivotal role in motor control and learning processes.

choices.text: It occurs due to the persistence of prochordal plate
It occurs due to the defective migration of primordial cells to the genital ridge
It contains skin, cartilage and bone
It is a benign tumor of coccyx

questions.text: Which of the following statements is wrong about the clinical pediatric case as shown in the image? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) It occurs due to the persistence of prochordal plate

 

 

 

The image shows a sacrococcygeal teratoma, which is a tumor located at the base of the coccyx in newborns. It is the most common tumor in neonates, and its origin and characteristics are well understood.

 

  • Persistence of Primitive Streak: Sacrococcygeal teratomas arise from the remnants of the primitive streak, not from the prochordal plate. The primitive streak is a structure in early embryonic development that usually regresses, but if remnants persist, they can lead to the formation of these tumors.
  • Defective Migration of Primordial Cells: This statement is correct as primordial germ cells that fail to migrate properly to the genital ridge can contribute to the formation of teratomas.
  • Contains Skin, Cartilage, and Bone: Teratomas are composed of tissues derived from all three germ layers: ectoderm, mesoderm, and endoderm. Therefore, they can contain a variety of tissue types including skin, cartilage, and bone.
  • Benign Tumor of Coccyx: Sacrococcygeal teratomas are generally benign, although they can sometimes be malignant.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Defective migration of primordial cells to the genital ridge: This statement is correct. Defective migration can result in teratomas.

 

Option C. Contains skin, cartilage, and bone: This statement is correct as teratomas can contain these tissues.

 

Option D. Benign tumor of coccyx: This statement is correct as sacrococcygeal teratomas are often benign.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sacrococcygeal teratomas arise from the remnants of the primitive streak and can contain various tissues including skin, cartilage, and bone. They are typically benign tumors located at the base of the coccyx.

questions.text: Decussation of the superior cerebellar peduncle occurs at which level?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Midbrain

 

Explanation:

 

The decussation of the superior cerebellar peduncle occurs in the midbrain, at the level of the inferior colliculus.

 

The midbrain has four decussations:

 

  • At the level of the superior colliculus:
    • Ventral tegmental decussation of the rubrospinal tract
    • Dorsal tegmental decussation of the tectospinal tract

 

 

  • At the level of the inferior colliculus:
    • Decussation of superior cerebellar peduncles
    • Decussation of trochlear nerve

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pons: The pons is a part of the brainstem located above the medulla and below the midbrain. It contains nuclei that deal with sleep, respiration, bladder control, hearing, taste, eye movement, facial expressions, facial sensation, and posture. While the pons does have connections with the cerebellum (mainly through the middle cerebellar peduncle), the decussation of the superior cerebellar peduncle doesn't happen here.

 

Option C. Diencephalon: The diencephalon is a region of the forebrain that includes the thalamus, hypothalamus, and epithalamus. While the superior cerebellar peduncle does send fibers to the thalamus, the decussation doesn't happen in the diencephalon.

 

Option D. Medulla: The medulla oblongata, commonly referred to simply as the medulla, is the lower part of the brainstem. It's continuous with the spinal cord and contains many important neural pathways and centers for autonomic functions. The medulla does contain decussations, but they are mainly associated with the pyramidal tracts (motor pathways) and not with the superior cerebellar peduncle.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The midbrain, or mesencephalon, is the uppermost part of the brainstem, lying between the pons and the diencephalon. The superior cerebellar peduncle fibers decussate (cross) in the midbrain to reach the contralateral red nucleus and thalamus. This is why lesions in the cerebellum typically affect the same side of the body: the fibers effectively "double-cross," first decussating in the midbrain and then crossing again at higher levels in the brain.

questions.text: Molecular defect causing liver disease in Dubin-Johnson syndrome is: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) ABCC2

 

Molecular defect causing liver disease in Dubin-Johnson syndrome is ABCC2 (codes for canalicular protein with ATP-binding cassette), it leads to the mutation of multiple drug-resistant protein 2 (MRP2) receptor. Hence, there is a defect in the transfer of conjugated bilirubin from the liver to bile in Dubin-Johnson syndrome.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. ATP7A: This gene is associated with Menkes disease, a disorder of copper metabolism.

 

Option B. ATP7B: This gene is associated with Wilson's disease, another disorder of copper metabolism.

 

Option D. SERPINA1: This gene is associated with Alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency, a condition that can lead to liver and lung disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The molecular defect causing liver disease in Dubin-Johnson syndrome is in the ABCC2 gene, which encodes for a canalicular protein involved in the excretion of conjugated bilirubin.

questions.text:
Which of the following cyanotic heart diseases causes increased pulmonary blood flow? (INICET MAY 2022)

 

  1. Ebstein anomaly
  2. Tetralogy of Fallot
  3. Transposition of the great arteries (TGA)
  4. Total anomalous pulmonary venous communication (TAPVC)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 3, 4

 

Transposition of the great arteries (TGA) and total anomalous pulmonary venous communication (TAPVC) are both cyanotic congenital heart diseases that cause increased pulmonary blood flow.

 

3. Transposition of the Great Arteries (TGA): In TGA, the positions of the pulmonary artery and the aorta are switched, which results in deoxygenated blood being circulated throughout the body. The mixing of oxygenated and deoxygenated blood occurs, leading to increased pulmonary blood flow because the deoxygenated blood is directed to the lungs.

 

4. Total Anomalous Pulmonary Venous Communication (TAPVC): In TAPVC, the pulmonary veins do not connect normally to the left atrium. Instead, they connect to the right atrium or systemic veins, causing a mixing of oxygenated and deoxygenated blood. This also leads to increased blood flow to the lungs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 1, 4: Ebstein anomaly does not cause increased pulmonary blood flow. Ebstein anomaly involves downward displacement of the tricuspid valve, leading to decreased pulmonary blood flow.

 

Option B. 1, 2: Both Ebstein anomaly and Tetralogy of Fallot cause decreased pulmonary blood flow. Tetralogy of Fallot includes pulmonary stenosis, which limits blood flow to the lungs.

 

Option D. 2, 4: Tetralogy of Fallot causes decreased pulmonary blood flow due to the presence of pulmonary stenosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cyanotic congenital heart diseases such as Transposition of the Great Arteries (TGA) and Total Anomalous Pulmonary Venous Communication (TAPVC) cause increased pulmonary blood flow.

questions.text: A patient's plasma has high levels of interferon beta. He most likely has an infection due to? (INICET NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Virus

 

Interferon-beta (IFN-β) is a type I interferon, which is predominantly secreted in response to viral infections. Interferons are proteins that play a crucial role in the immune response to pathogens, particularly viruses. They help inhibit viral replication within host cells and activate immune cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Bacteria: Bacterial infections are primarily associated with pro-inflammatory cytokines like IL-1, TNF-α, and IL-6, rather than type I interferons.

 

Option C. Fungi: Fungal infections do not typically induce high levels of interferon-beta.

 

Option D. Mycoplasm: Mycoplasma infections are more likely to induce other immune responses rather than a significant increase in interferon-beta.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Types of interferons:

questions.text:
Which of the following are signs of heart failure? (INICET NOV 2022)

 

  1. Non-pulsatile rise of JVP
  2. Orthopnea
  3. Dyspnea after 2 hours of sleep
  4. Right upper quadrant pain/Right hypochondrial pain
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 2, 3, 4

 

Heart failure presents with a range of symptoms due to the inability of the heart to pump blood effectively. The following signs are indicative of heart failure:

 

  • Orthopnea (Option 2): This is difficulty breathing when lying flat and is a common symptom of left-sided heart failure.
  • Dyspnea after 2 hours of sleep (Option 3): Also known as paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea (PND), this occurs due to fluid redistribution during sleep, leading to pulmonary congestion.
  • Right upper quadrant pain/Right hypochondrial pain (Option 4): This is associated with right-sided heart failure leading to congestive hepatomegaly.

 

Other Options:

 

Option 1 (Non-pulsatile rise of JVP): This is incorrect as heart failure typically causes a pulsatile rise in jugular venous pressure (JVP). A non-pulsatile rise in JVP is usually indicative of superior vena cava (SVC) obstruction, not heart failure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Signs of heart failure include orthopnea, paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea (PND), and right upper quadrant pain due to congestive hepatomegaly.

choices.text: A positive correlation
A negative correlation

questions.text:
A researcher is conducting a study to explore the relationship between body mass index (BMI) and blood pressure in a cohort of 100 adults with varying degrees of obesity and hypertension. The scatter plot generated from the data displays BMI on the y-axis and a modified blood pressure value on the x-axis. The data points appear to cluster along a trajectory.

 

Based on this scatter plot, what is the most likely statistical relationship between BMI and blood pressure in this population?
questions.solution:
Answer: A) A positive correlation

 

Explanation:

 

A scatter/dot diagram visually represents the relationship between two continuous variables. In this case, the diagram shows that as BMI increases, systolic blood pressure (SBP) also increases, indicating a positive correlation. A positive correlation occurs when higher values of one variable (BMI) are associated with higher values of another variable (SBP).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B) A negative correlation: A negative correlation would show a trend where one variable increases while the other decreases, which is not the case here.

 

Option C) No correlation: If there was no correlation, the points on the scatter plot would be randomly distributed with no discernible pattern or trend between BMI and SBP.

 

Option D) A perfect correlation: A perfect correlation means all points would lie exactly on a straight line, which is rarely seen in biological data due to natural variability.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A scatter/dot diagram helps visualize the relationship between two continuous variables. A positive correlation occurs when both variables increase together, as demonstrated in the relationship between BMI and systolic blood pressure.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient visits you with inflammatory alopecia. This type of hair loss is commonly associated with which variant of tinea capitis infection? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Favus and Kerion

 

Favus and kerion are the inflammatory variants of tinea capitis.

 

Tinea capitis variants:

 

 

Kerion presents in Children with boggy swelling, easily pluckable hair, with regional lymphadenopathy. It is a severe inflammatory type of tinea capitis. The. In severe cases, there may be pus along with sinus formation.

 

Kerion:

 

 

  • Lesion: boggy indurated scalp swelling
  • Easily pluckable hair associated with regional lymphadenopathy
  • Most common causative organisms:  Zoophilic dermatophytes i.e., T. verrucosum and T. mentagrophytes.
  • Investigation: 10% KOH mount
  • Treatment: DOC overall and for Microsporum àGriseofulvin

 

Note: DOC for Trichophyton is Terbinafine.

 

Other Options

 

Option A: Endothrix and Favus and Option D: Kerion and Endothrix Endothrix infections involve the growth of fungi within the hair shaft without external spore formation and typically present with less inflammation compared to Kerion and Favus.

 

Option B: Ectothrix and Endothrix Ectothrix infections, where the fungus grows on the outside of the hair shaft and breaks the hair off at the scalp surface, are typically associated with non-inflammatory forms of alopecia such as the 'grey patch' type.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Inflammatory alopecia is commonly associated with the favus and kerion variants of tinea capitis, which can cause scarring and permanent hair loss due to the significant inflammatory response.

 

 

Reference:  Rook's Textbook of Dermatology - Volume II-9th Edition Page no 32.39-40, 89.35

questions.text: Which of the following components of the fungal cell wall is not seen in mucormycosis? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Beta 1, 3, glucan

 

An abundant cell wall polysaccharide, (1-3)-β-d-glucan (BDG) is found in most fungi, with the notable exception of the cryptococci, the zygomycetes (mucor and Rhizopus), and Blastomyces dermatitidis, which either lack the glucan entirely or produce it at minimal levels.

 

Fungal cell wall:

 

  • Fungal cell walls are rigid and contain complex polysaccharides called chitin (adds structural strength) and glucans.
  • Ergosterol is the steroid molecule in the cell membranes that replaces the cholesterol found in animal cell membranes.

 

Clinical significance of Beta-1, 3-d-glucan:

 

G-test: Detects a-3 glucan. Used in diagnosis of candidiasis.

 

Tests for beta-d-glucan: Raised levels are seen in candidiasis, aspergillosis, and pneumonia due to Pneumocystis carnii.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mannoproteins: Mannoproteins are glycoproteins found in the fungal cell wall, contributing to its structure and function.

 

Option C. Chitin: Chitin is a structural polysaccharide found in the cell walls of fungi, including those causing mucormycosis. It provides rigidity and strength to the cell wall.

 

Option D. Ergosterol: Ergosterol is a component of fungal cell membranes, not the cell wall. It replaces cholesterol found in animal cell membranes and is essential for maintaining membrane integrity and function in fungi.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Beta 1, 3, glucan is absent or minimally present in the cell walls of fungi causing mucormycosis, distinguishing them from many other fungi that have this polysaccharide as a major cell wall component. This characteristic is significant in the diagnosis and treatment of fungal infections.

questions.text:
In the given section of the heart, match the marked (4, 9, 12, 1) structures:

 

  1. Outflow to pulmonary trunk (blue)
  2. Mitral valve
  3. Tricuspid valve
  4. Papillary muscles
questions.solution:
Ans. C. a-1, b-4, c-9, D-12

 

Explanation:

 

The image shows a cut and reflected section of the heart.

 

The ventricles can be identified based upon the wall thickness - Left ventricle has thicker walls.

 

  1. Outflow to pulmonary trunk (marked as 1): This structure represents the exit point for blood traveling to the lungs for oxygenation.
  2. Mitral valve (marked as 4): Located between the left atrium and the left ventricle, the mitral valve regulates blood flow within the heart.
  3. Tricuspid valve (marked as 9): This valve, situated between the right atrium and right ventricle, prevents backflow of blood from the ventricles to the atria.
  4. Papillary muscles (marked as 12): These muscles are attached to the ventricular walls and play a critical role in the function of the mitral and tricuspid valves via tendon-like chords.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct match is:

 

1. Outflow to pulmonary trunk (blue)

2. Left atrium

3. Pulmonary veins (light red)

4. Mitral valve

5. Aorta (red).

6. Superior vena cava (blue)

7. Aortic semi lunar valve

8. Right atrium

9. Tricuspid valve

10. Right ventricle

11. Inferior vena cave (blue)

12. Papillary muscles

13. Left ventricle

questions.text:
A 62-year-old male patient with heart failure is scheduled for a heart transplant. His renal function test is deranged, and hemoglobin is 6 g/dL. The physician ordered 2 units of whole blood. Four hours after transfusion, he developed severe respiratory distress. On examination, he is hypoxemic, has tachycardia, and his mean arterial pressure is elevated. Which of the following are the best investigations for the above scenario? (INICET NOV 2021)

 

  1. Chest X-ray
  2. Brain natriuretic peptide (BNP) level
  3. Absolute neutrophil count
  4. Leucocyte antibodies
  5. Platelets
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1 and 2

 

The patient presents with signs and symptoms indicative of transfusion-associated circulatory overload (TACO), which includes elevated mean arterial pressure, hypoxemia, and respiratory distress following a blood transfusion. TACO occurs due to fluid overload from the transfusion, leading to pulmonary edema and increased cardiac filling pressures.

 

1. Chest X-ray: This imaging is crucial as it can reveal bilateral infiltrates indicative of pulmonary edema, a hallmark of TACO. It helps to differentiate between TACO and other causes of respiratory distress post-transfusion.

 

2. Brain Natriuretic Peptide (BNP) Level: BNP is a cardiac biomarker that is elevated in conditions of increased cardiac pressure and volume overload, such as TACO. Elevated BNP levels would support the diagnosis of TACO, whereas BNP levels would not be elevated in transfusion-related acute lung injury (TRALI), another potential complication post-transfusion that presents with respiratory distress but usually with hypotension.

 

Other Options:

 

3. Absolute neutrophil count and 5. platelets are not specific for diagnosing TACO or TRALI. These parameters do not provide information on fluid overload or cardiac stress.

 

4. Leucocyte antibodies are not directly relevant to the diagnosis of TACO. Leucocyte antibodies might be involved in TRALI, but not TACO.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a patient with suspected transfusion-associated circulatory overload (TACO), the best investigations are a chest X-ray to detect pulmonary edema and BNP levels to assess cardiac stress and fluid overload

questions.text: In urea cycle disorders, which of the following can be used to reduce the levels of ammonia?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Phenylbutyrate

 

In urea cycle disorders ammonia cannot be converted to urea, but alternatively can be converted to glutamine and glycine. Ammonia scavengers phenylbutyrate and sodium benzoate react with glutamine and glycine and consequently remove excess of ammonia. Phenylglutamine and hippurate are excreted in urine.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Glutamate: While glutamate can bind ammonia to form glutamine, it does not directly reduce ammonia levels through excretion.

 

Option C. Isoleucine: An amino acid that does not have a role in reducing ammonia levels in urea cycle disorders.

 

Option D. L-carnitine: Involved in the transport of fatty acids into mitochondria for beta-oxidation, but it does not play a role in reducing ammonia levels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Phenylbutyrate is used in urea cycle disorders to reduce ammonia levels by converting ammonia into phenylacetylglutamine, which is then excreted in the urine.

questions.text: A baby assessed 5 minutes after birth is found to be pink, with blue extremities, and irregular respiration. Heart rate is 80 beats per minute. There is grimace and some flexion. What is the Apgar score for this baby? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 5

 

The Apgar score for this baby will be 5.

 

 

  • Color: body pink, extremities blue: score-1
  • Heart rate: 80 beats per minute: score 1
  • Grimace: Score-1
  • Some flexion: Score-1
  • Irregular respiration: Score-1

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Apgar score is used to quickly assess the overall health of a newborn, with a score of 5 indicating the need for some medical intervention but not immediate resuscitation.

choices.text: Randomization of participants
Data extraction and coding
Statistical synthesis of results

questions.text:
A clinical researcher is conducting a meta-analysis to assess the overall effectiveness of a new antihypertensive drug by pooling data from multiple randomized controlled trials. The researcher follows standard procedures for meta-analysis. During the review, the researcher realizes that one common trial component is not part of the meta-analysis process.

 

Which of the following is not a key component of the meta-analysis process?
questions.solution:
Answer: B) Randomization of participants

 

Explanation:

 

Randomization of participants is a key feature of clinical trials, not meta-analysis. In clinical trials, participants are randomly assigned to different treatment groups to ensure comparability and minimize bias. However, a meta-analysis involves systematically reviewing and statistically analyzing data from previously completed studies. The researcher does not randomize participants in a meta-analysis, as the data have already been collected from clinical trials or observational studies.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A) Problem formulation: This is a key step in meta-analysis, where the research question or hypothesis is clearly defined.

 

Option C) Data extraction and coding: In meta-analysis, data from relevant studies are extracted, coded, and appraised for quality to ensure that the analysis is accurate and reliable.

 

Option D) Statistical synthesis of results: Meta-analysis involves combining the results of individual studies through statistical techniques to provide an overall estimate of the effect being studied.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A meta-analysis systematically combines data from multiple studies to generate a comprehensive understanding of a research question. Randomization of participants is a component of clinical trials, not meta-analysis.

questions.text: Maternal antibodies do not provide significant immunity in a neonate against: (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Polio

 

While infants can acquire polio antibodies from their mothers, this immunity is not consistent and can fade during infancy. Therefore, newborns are given a 0 dose of polio drops to ensure protection against the virus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tetanus: Maternal antibodies against tetanus can provide significant immunity to the newborn. Pregnant women are advised to receive the Tdap vaccine during each pregnancy, ideally between 27-36 weeks of gestation. Maternal antibodies produced from the vaccine can protect the newborn against tetanus.

 

Option C. Diphtheria: Maternal antibodies provide some protection, but it's less reliable than tetanus


Protection duration is shorter (1-2 months)

 

Option D. Measles: Maternal antibodies help protect the baby from measles until about 9 months of age. After that, the efficacy of maternal antibodies decreases, which is why the measles vaccine is given at 9 months of life.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Maternal antibodies do not provide consistent and lasting immunity against polio in neonates, necessitating early vaccination with polio drops.

questions.text: A young patient presented with hypoparathyroidism, absent thymus and tetany. Which of the following marked areas in the picture is defective in this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 12

 

Explanation:

 

The given clinical scenario of hypoparathyroidism, absent thymus, and tetany is suggestive of DiGeorge syndrome. It is caused by defective development of the third and fourth pharyngeal pouch.

 

In the image of pharyngeal pouches, "12" points to the thymus (derivative of 3rd pharyngeal pouch). Since in the above question, the thymus is absent, option 3 will be the most appropriate answer.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. (1): 1st Pharyngeal pouches, which is unrelated to the thymus or parathyroid glands directly involved in this case.

 

Option B. (10): External auditory meatus, which is not implicated in DiGeorge syndrome.

 

Option D. (13): Superior parathyroid gland, derived from the fourth pharyngeal pouch. Although it's closely related to the condition described, the primary indicator in this scenario, given the patient's symptoms, is the thymus rather than the parathyroid glands.

 

Educational Objective:

 

DiGeorge syndrome, also known as 22q11.2 deletion syndrome, is a genetic disorder caused by a missing piece of chromosome 22. It is characterized by a wide range of symptoms that can vary in severity, but are typically grouped together as mnemonic CATCH -22

 

Mnemonic "CATCH-22":

 

C - Cardiac abnormalities, such as ventricular septal defects (VSD) and tetralogy of Fallot.

 

A - Abnormal facies, including a small chin, low-set ears, and wide-set eyes.

 

T - Thymic aplasia or hypoplasia, leading to a weakened immune system.

 

C - Cleft palate or other palate abnormalities.

 

H - Hypocalcemia or low levels of calcium due to underdeveloped or missing parathyroid glands.

 

22 - Refers to the chromosome 22q11.2 deletion, which causes the syndrome.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male presents with golden-brown ring over iris on examination. What next is done to diagnose the condition? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Serum ceruloplasmin

 

This is the most relevant test for the suspected condition. Wilson's disease is a rare inherited disorder that causes copper to accumulate in the liver, brain, and other vital organs. Ceruloplasmin is a protein that binds copper in the bloodstream. In Wilson's disease, serum ceruloplasmin levels are typically low. Testing serum ceruloplasmin is a key diagnostic step for Wilson's disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Serum Iron Level: While important in diagnosing conditions related to iron metabolism such as hemochromatosis or iron-deficiency anemia, serum iron levels are not directly relevant for diagnosing Wilson's disease. Hemochromatosis can also lead to liver damage but doesn't cause Kayser-Fleischer rings.

 

Option C. Alpha-1 Antitrypsin: This test is used to diagnose alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency, a genetic condition that can cause lung and liver disease. However, it is not related to the presence of Kayser-Fleischer rings and would not be the appropriate next step in this scenario.

 

Option D. Alpha-Fetoprotein: This is a marker often used in the diagnosis of liver cancers, particularly hepatocellular carcinoma. While liver dysfunction is a component of Wilson's disease, alpha-fetoprotein is not a diagnostic marker for Wilson's disease and would not be the best next step in this context.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When a patient presents with Kayser-Fleischer rings, it is crucial to evaluate for Wilson's disease, a condition of abnormal copper metabolism. Serum ceruloplasmin is a key diagnostic test in this situation. Understanding the appropriate diagnostic approach for specific clinical signs is essential in guiding effective and efficient patient care.

choices.text: Primary sclerosing cholangitis

questions.text: Cholangiocarcinoma is not a complication of?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hepatitis B

 

Cholangiocarcinoma is a cancer that forms in the bile ducts. It is associated with various risk factors and conditions, but Hepatitis B is not directly linked to its development. Hepatitis B virus (HBV) is primarily associated with hepatocellular carcinoma, which is a different type of liver cancer. The other options listed are known risk factors for cholangiocarcinoma.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Opisthorchis: This parasitic infection is a known risk factor for cholangiocarcinoma. 

 

Option B. Primary sclerosing cholangitis: This chronic liver disease involving inflammation and scarring of the bile ducts is a significant risk factor for developing cholangiocarcinoma.

 

Option C. Caroli's disease: This congenital disorder characterized by cystic dilatation of intrahepatic bile ducts increases the risk of cholangiocarcinoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hepatitis B virus primarily causes hepatocellular carcinoma, not cholangiocarcinoma, unlike other liver conditions such as parasitic infections, primary sclerosing cholangitis, and Caroli's disease.

choices.text: Give progesterone and stop after 10 days for withdrawal bleeding

questions.text: A 25-year-old female came with complaints of 4 months amenorrhea. Her FSH and LH were elevated above the normal value, thyroid function tests were normal. Which is the next step in management? (INICET MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Give progesterone and stop after 10 days for withdrawal bleeding

 

Explanation

 

  • Since LH and FSH are elevated above the normal value, the possibility of a pregnancy can be ruled out as FSH and LH levels fall to very low levels in pregnancy
  • The first step in evaluation of secondary amenorrhoea after ruling out pregnancy is to do a progesterone challenge test i.e. to see if she bleeds after a challenge of progesterone.
  • If she bleeds, the diagnosis is anovulation like in PCOS

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Estimate serum estradiol values: Serum estradiol level measurement has no role in evaluation of secondary amenorrhoea

 

Option D. Do a urine pregnancy test: FSH levels in pregnancy are very very low so pregnancy is unlikely; otherwise the most common cause of secondary amenorrhoea is pregnancy

 

Option C. Check USG for Polycystic ovaries: This is done if the patient bleeds following progesterone withdrawal as it determines the cause of anovular cycles

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Secondary amenorrhea is defined as a period of amenorrhoea of 6 months
  • Pregnancy needs to be ruled out
  • The most common cause of secondary amenorrhea after ruling out pregnancy is anovulation (PCOS) which can be determined by the progesterone withdrawal test

 

Ref: Page no 457, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6th edition

questions.text: A dead body is brought for evaluation. On post-mortem examination, a ligature that was completely encircling the neck, horizontal, and below the level of the thyroid was seen. There was no dribbling of saliva. What is the cause of death? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ligature strangulation  

 

The presence of a ligature mark that completely encircles the neck, is horizontal, and located below the level of the thyroid cartilage is indicative of ligature strangulation. This type of mark differentiates it from other forms of neck compression injuries.

 

Additional Clues:

 

  • Dribbling of Saliva: The absence of dribbling of saliva suggests that the cause of death is not hanging. Dribbling of saliva is the surest sign of antemortem hanging.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Throttling: Throttling involves manual strangulation using hands, not a ligature. It would show different injury patterns on the neck.

 

Option C. Gagging: Gagging involves the insertion of a foreign object into the mouth to prevent breathing, which would show different internal and external signs.

 

Option D. Hanging: Hanging would typically show a ligature mark that is oblique and above the level of the thyroid cartilage, along with signs such as dribbling of saliva.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Increase in IL-2, IL-4 and IL-5

questions.text: Mechanism of thalidomide teratogenicity include all except
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Increase in IL-2, IL-4 and IL-5

 

Thalidomide actually suppresses the production of certain cytokines, including IL-2, IL-4, and IL-5. The suppression of these interleukins is part of its immunomodulatory effects, not a mechanism of teratogenicity. Thalidomide suppresses the production of interleukins which is an important mechanism in treatment of multiple myeloma.

 

The exact mechanism of thalidomide's teratogenicity is not completely understood, but several mechanisms have been proposed:

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Inhibition of angiogenesis: Thalidomide has been found to inhibit angiogenesis, which is the formation of new blood vessels. This inhibition can disrupt the development of the fetus, leading to birth defects. This mechanism is widely accepted as a significant contributor to the teratogenic effects of thalidomide.

 

Option C. Generation of oxygen free radicals: Thalidomide may cause oxidative stress by generating oxygen free radicals, which can damage developing cells. This oxidative stress can contribute to teratogenic effects.

 

Option D. Binding to cereblon: Recent studies have shown that thalidomide binds to a protein called cereblon, which is involved in limb outgrowth and ear development. When thalidomide binds to cereblon, it disrupts the normal function of this protein, leading to the birth defects associated with thalidomide use.

 

Other mechanism includes -

 

  • Interference with cellular signalling: Thalidomide may interfere with various cellular signalling pathways, such as those involving fibroblast growth factors, which are important for embryonic development.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Thalidomide's teratogenicity is primarily associated with mechanisms such as the inhibition of angiogenesis, generation of oxygen free radicals, and binding to the cereblon protein. It does not cause an increase in IL-2, IL-4, and IL-5; in fact, it suppresses these interleukins.

questions.text: Given the particular appearance and characteristics of the box-whisker plot as shown below, which of the following statements most accurately describes the relationships between the mean, median, and mode? [AIIMS MAY 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Mean > Median > Mode 

 

  • The provided box-whisker plot illustrates a distribution that is positively skewed (right skewed).
  • In a positively skewed distribution, the mean > median > mode.
  • To further understand and correlate the fact, have a look at the following images:

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In Right skew curve: Mean > Median > Mode
  • In Left skew curve: Mean < Median < Mode
  • In Normal distribution: Mean = Median = Mode.

choices.text: Subcutaneous sumatriptan and high-flow oxygen

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presents to the emergency department with severe, recurrent unilateral headaches that he describes as excruciating and lasting from 15 to 180 minutes. He experiences these headaches multiple times per day, often accompanied by symptoms such as tearing and nasal congestion. The intensity of the pain causes significant distress. What is the most appropriate treatment for an acute attack of this condition?
questions.solution:
Answer: C) Subcutaneous sumatriptan and high-flow oxygen

 

Explanation:

 

Cluster headache is a type of Trigeminal Autonomic Cephalalgia (TAC) characterized by severe, unilateral pain with autonomic symptoms such as lacrimation, nasal congestion, and restlessness. The hallmark of cluster headaches is the intense, “suicidal” nature of the pain and its recurrent nature, often described as the most severe form of headache.

 

Acute Attack Management:

 

Subcutaneous Sumatriptan (6 mg) and high-flow oxygen (100% O2 at 8-10 L/min) are the most effective treatments for acute attacks of cluster headaches. Sumatriptan provides rapid relief due to its quick onset of action, and high-flow oxygen can significantly alleviate symptoms without systemic effects.

 

Preventive/Prophylactic Treatment:

 

Prophylaxis plays a critical role in cluster headache management, with medications such as high-dose steroids, verapamil, and lithium often initiated during the cluster period to reduce attack frequency and severity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A) Indomethacin: Typically effective for other TACs but not the treatment of choice for cluster headaches.

 

Option B) Oral triptans: While useful in some headache disorders, they are less effective in the rapid termination of acute cluster headache attacks compared to the subcutaneous form.

 

Option D) IV lidocaine: Primarily used for a different type of TAC and not effective in managing acute cluster headache attacks.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The treatment of choice for acute cluster headache attacks is subcutaneous sumatriptan combined with high-flow oxygen. These interventions provide rapid and effective relief, which is crucial in managing the severe and distressing symptoms associated with cluster headaches. Preventive therapies are also essential to reduce the frequency of future attacks.

choices.text: Increased Amino acids
Raised glucose

questions.text: A 60-year-old lady with diabetes mellitus comes with dizziness. Which of the following would be seen in a patient with hyperinsulinemia?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Increased fatty acid synthesis

 

Explanation:  

 

Hyperinsulinemia refers to an elevated level of insulin in the blood.

 

Insulin is a lipogenic hormone, meaning it promotes the synthesis of fatty acids and their storage as triglycerides in adipose tissue. This is due to insulin's ability to activate enzymes involved in lipogenesis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hyper-ketonemia: Incorrect. Insulin suppresses ketone production, so hyperinsulinemia would prevent the formation of ketone bodies.

 

Option B. Increased Amino acids: Incorrect. Insulin promotes protein synthesis and reduces the level of amino acids in the blood by enhancing their uptake into cells and their incorporation into proteins.

 

Option C. Raised glucose: Incorrect. Hyperinsulinemia lowers blood glucose levels by promoting glucose uptake into cells and inhibiting gluconeogenesis and glycogenolysis in the liver.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hyperinsulinemia promotes increased fatty acid synthesis due to insulin's role as a lipogenic hormone, which enhances the storage of energy in the form of fat.

choices.text: Gently replace the cord inside the vagina
Inform the doctor and shift to OT
Do vaginal examination and find the fetal presentation

questions.text: A midwife is examining a pregnant woman in labour when she noticed that there is cord prolapse. What should be the next immediate step of management? (INICET MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Put her in Trendelenburg position

 

Cord prolapse is an obstetric emergency where the umbilical cord slips ahead of the presenting part of the fetus in the birth canal, leading to compression of the cord. This compression can restrict blood flow and oxygen to the fetus, causing fetal distress or hypoxia.

 

The immediate management of cord prolapse includes:

 

  • Relieving pressure off the cord: This is crucial to prevent fetal hypoxia. This can be achieved by positioning the patient in a way that minimizes pressure on the cord.
  • Trendelenburg position: This position involves tilting the patient’s body with the head down and the pelvis up. This helps to shift the fetal presenting part off the prolapsed cord and relieves compression.
  • Left lateral position or All-fours position: Alternative positions can also help in relieving pressure on the cord.

 

While preparing for an emergency cesarean section (LSCS) to deliver the fetus urgently, these positions and techniques are used to temporarily alleviate the pressure on the cord.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gently replace the cord inside the vagina: Attempting to reposition the cord is not recommended as it can cause further damage or spasm of the vessels in the cord.

 

Option B. Inform the doctor and shift to OT: While informing the doctor and preparing for cesarean delivery is necessary, immediate steps to relieve cord compression should be taken first.

 

Option D. Do vaginal examination and find the fetal presentation: This may be done, but the primary focus should be on relieving the pressure on the cord immediately to prevent fetal distress.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the case of cord prolapse, placing the patient in Trendelenburg position helps to relieve pressure on the prolapsed cord and is a critical step in managing the emergency until a cesarean section can be performed.

 

Ref: Page 1129, Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition

questions.text: Which of the following has the least conduction velocity? (NEET PG  2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Postganglionic sympathetic fibers

 

Postganglionic sympathetic fibers, also known as type C fibers, are known for their small diameter and lack of myelin sheath, characteristics that contribute to their slow conduction velocity compared to other nerve fiber types. These fibers are involved in the sympathetic nervous system, carrying impulses from the autonomic ganglia to the target organs. The absence of myelin significantly reduces their conduction speed because myelin acts as an insulator that enhances the speed of nerve impulse conduction through saltatory conduction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Somatic motor fibers: These fibers, typically myelinated and larger in diameter, conduct impulses much faster. They are involved in controlling voluntary muscle movements.

 

Option C. Pre-ganglionic autonomic fibers: Generally myelinated though smaller than somatic motor fibers, pre-ganglionic fibers also conduct impulses faster than postganglionic sympathetic fibers.

 

Option D. Touch and pressure fibers: These sensory fibers are usually myelinated and conduct impulses at high speeds, facilitating rapid response to sensory stimuli.

 

Additional Information:

 

  • Conduction Velocity Factors: The speed at which a nerve fiber conducts an electrical impulse is influenced by its diameter and whether or not it is myelinated. Larger diameter and myelination both contribute to faster conduction velocities.
  • Type C Fibers: These are the smallest and slowest conducting fibers due to their lack of myelination. They typically transmit nociceptive (pain) and sympathetic autonomic signals.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Among the options given, postganglionic sympathetic fibers (Type C fibers) have the least conduction velocity due to their small diameter and lack of myelin, which make them slower in transmitting nerve impulses compared to myelinated fibers.

questions.text: Which of the below agents cause hypertension when consumed?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Cocaine

 

Cocaine is a stimulant (sympathomimetic) drug that typically leads to an increase in heart rate and blood pressure due to its effects on the cardiovascular system.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Organophosphorus: Organophosphorus compounds are cholinesterase inhibitors and cause cholinergic symptoms like bradycardia, hypotension, salivation, lacrimation, urination, defecation, gastrointestinal distress, and emesis (SLUDGE syndrome). They do not cause hypertension.

 

Option B. Phosphorus: Phosphorus poisoning typically leads to gastrointestinal symptoms (vomiting, diarrhea), jaundice, hepatic and renal failure. It does not cause hypertension.

 

Option C. Arsenic: Arsenic poisoning can cause a range of symptoms including gastrointestinal distress, peripheral neuropathy, skin changes (rain drop pigmentation), Mees' lines on nails, and long-term effects like cancer. It does not cause hypertension.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cocaine is a sympathomimetic drug and has stimulant effects on CNS and cardiovascular system as mentioned below:

 

  • Agitation and Restlessness
  • Tachycardia / Palpitations
  • Hypertension
  • Dilated Pupils
  • Profuse Sweating
  • Hyperthermia
  • Restlessness
  • Paranoia and hallucinations.
  • Serious Cardiovascular Effects: Arrhythmias, Myocardial Infarction
  • Respiratory Distress: Rapid, shallow breathing and respiratory distress.
  • Seizures, Confusion and Altered Mental Status

choices.text: NK cells, neutrophils and eosinophils

questions.text: Antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity (ADCC) is seen with: (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) NK cells, neutrophils and eosinophils

 

Antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity (ADCC) is mediated by NK cells, neutrophils and eosinophils (killing certain parasitic worms like helminths via lgE antibodies).

 

In ADCC, cells/ antigens are coated with IgG antibodies. These are killed by effector cells like NK cells and macrophages. These effector cells bind to the target by their receptors for the Fc fragment of IgG and cell lysis proceeds without phagocytosis.

 

 

Role of NK Cells: NK cells are key mediators of ADCC. They express the Fc receptor CD16 (FcγRIII), which specifically recognizes the Fc portion of IgG antibodies bound to target cells. Upon engagement, NK cells degranulate, releasing cytotoxic molecules that induce apoptosis in the target cell.

 

Role of Neutrophils and Eosinophils: Eosinophils are particularly involved in the ADCC response against larger parasites, such as helminths, where they utilize IgE antibodies to recognize and attack these pathogens.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity (ADCC) is primarily mediated by NK cells, neutrophils, and eosinophils, which kill target cells coated with antibodies through mechanisms that do not involve phagocytosis.

 

Ref: Robbins pathologic basis of disease, 8th edition, Pg no. 356

questions.text: Identify the type of inhibition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C)  Non competitive

 

Explanation :

 

The graph illustrates enzyme kinetics in the presence of an inhibitor, showing that the Km (Michaelis constant) remains the same, whereas the Vmax (maximum velocity) decreases. This pattern is characteristic of non-competitive inhibition. In non-competitive inhibition, the inhibitor binds to an enzyme at a site other than the active site, which alters the enzyme's function but does not affect the substrate's binding affinity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Competitive: In competitive inhibition, the inhibitor competes with the substrate for binding at the active site. This increases Km but does not change Vmax.

 

Option B. Uncompetitive: In uncompetitive inhibition, the inhibitor binds only to the enzyme-substrate complex, decreasing both Km and Vmax.

 

Option D. Suicidal: Suicidal inhibition involves the inhibitor binding irreversibly to the enzyme, effectively inactivating it. This type of inhibition is not typically represented by simple kinetic plots.

 

Educational Objective

 

Summary of effect of different Inhibitors

questions.text: A patient presents with fever, nocturnal cough, breathlessness, and wheezing for 4 weeks. Absolute eosinophil count > 5000/μL. Chest X-ray shows a miliary pattern. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Tropical pulmonary eosinophilia

 

Tropical pulmonary eosinophilia (TPE) is a condition caused by the presence of microfilariae in the pulmonary circulation, leading to a severe immune response characterized by significant eosinophilia. The clinical presentation includes fever, nocturnal cough, breathlessness, and wheezing, which are symptoms consistent with TPE. The absolute eosinophil count greater than 5000/μL further supports this diagnosis.

 

The chest X-ray finding of a miliary pattern, though more commonly associated with tuberculosis, can also be seen in TPE due to the diffuse infiltration of eosinophils in the lungs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bronchial asthma: Asthma can present with wheezing and nocturnal symptoms but is not typically associated with a miliary pattern on chest X-ray or such a high level of eosinophilia.

 

Option B. Miliary tuberculosis: Miliary tuberculosis can present with a miliary pattern on chest X-ray but is not associated with a significantly elevated eosinophil count. Miliary TB usually presents with systemic symptoms like weight loss, night sweats, and widespread dissemination in the body.

 

Option D. Hypersensitivity pneumonitis: This condition can cause pulmonary symptoms and may present with a miliary pattern on imaging. However, it is usually a type III hypersensitivity reaction (immune complex-mediated) and does not typically lead to such high levels of eosinophilia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tropical pulmonary eosinophilia is characterized by symptoms like fever, nocturnal cough, breathlessness, wheezing, significant eosinophilia, and a miliary pattern on chest X-ray. This diagnosis should be considered in patients presenting with these clinical findings, especially in endemic regions. The treatment of choice for TPE is diethylcarbamazine (DEC).

questions.text: You're mentoring a group of budding epidemiologists who are keen on understanding the nuances of different study designs. One of them is particularly interested in case-control studies. To test their knowledge, you decide to quiz them on aspects that are typically not inherent to case-control studies. Which of the following elements would not usually be part of a case-control study?
questions.solution:
Answer: C) Follow-up of participants

 

Follow-up of participants is not a typical component of case-control studies, as these studies are retrospective and analyze exposures that occurred in the past. Unlike cohort studies, which involve following participants over time to assess outcomes, case-control studies look backward to identify exposures related to the current status of cases and controls.

 

Other Options:

 

Case-control studies are observational studies that involve comparing two groups—cases (those with the condition of interest) and controls (those without the condition)—to identify factors that may be associated with the outcome. Key aspects of case-control studies include:

 

Option A. Matching of Cases and Controls: This process ensures that controls are similar to cases regarding certain variables, reducing the impact of confounding factors.

 

Option B. Calculation of Odds Ratio: Since case-control studies cannot directly calculate incidence or relative risk, the strength of association between exposure and outcome is measured using an Odds Ratio (OR), which estimates the relative risk.

 

Option D. Selection of Two Groups (Cases and Controls): This is a fundamental aspect of the study design, ensuring that comparisons can be made between those affected and those unaffected by the condition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Case-control studies are retrospective, focusing on comparing cases and controls to identify associations between exposures and outcomes. They do not involve follow-up of participants, distinguishing them from cohort studies, which do include follow-up to assess outcomes over time. Understanding these distinctions helps in correctly designing and interpreting observational studies.

questions.text:
Acid-base imbalance is suspected in a patient. Which of the following would you use to determine it? (INICET MAY 2021)

 

  1. Arterial pH
  2. Venous pH
  3. Venous pO2
  4. Venous pCO2
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1, 2, 4

 

Arterial pH is the gold standard for acid-base analysis as it directly measures the hydrogen ion concentration in arterial blood, providing a precise assessment of the patient's acid-base status. Venous pH and venous pCO2 can also provide reliable information about the patient’s acid-base status and are often used in clinical settings where arterial blood gas (ABG) analysis is not feasible.

 

1. Arterial pH and 2. Venous pH:  Arterial pH: This is the most accurate method for assessing acid-base balance. Arterial pH varies by only 0.03 to 0.05 from venous pH. To estimate arterial pH from venous pH, add 0.03 to 0.05.

 

4. Venous pCO2: To estimate arterial pCO2 (PaCO2) from venous pCO2, subtract 5 from venous pCO2.

 

Venous pH and venous pCO2 can be used in some situations to predict arterial values.

 

Other Options:
 

3. Venous pO2 is not useful for determining acid-base imbalance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Arterial pH, venous pH, and venous pCO2 are used to determine acid-base imbalances.

questions.text: What does this Cardio-Tocography show?  (INICET MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Deceleration

 

Explanation:

 

The Cardio-Tocography (CTG) in question shows decelerations, which are characterized by a drop in the fetal heart rate (FHR) by at least 15 beats per minute (bpm) lasting for at least 15 seconds.

 

Types of Decelerations on CTG:

 

  1. Early Deceleration:
    • The nadir (lowest point) of the deceleration corresponds with the peak of the uterine contraction.
    • Caused by head compression during contractions.
    • Commonly observed in the second stage of labor.
  2. Late Deceleration:
    • The nadir of the deceleration occurs after the peak of the contraction.
    • Indicative of uteroplacental insufficiency, which can lead to fetal distress or hypoxia.
    • Considered an ominous sign and requires prompt evaluation and intervention.
  3. Variable Deceleration:
    • There is no fixed relationship between the deceleration and uterine contractions.
    • Caused by umbilical cord compression, often seen with oligohydramnios.
    • Significant if persistent, with FHR <70 bpm for more than 60 seconds.
  4. Prolonged Deceleration:
    • Occurs when the deceleration lasts beyond 2 minutes but less than 10 minutes.
    • May indicate acute fetal hypoxia, such as with cord prolapse or intrapartum abruption.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Acceleration: This would show an increase in the fetal heart rate by at least 15 bpm lasting for at least 15 seconds, which is not the case here.

 

Option C. Normal: A normal CTG would not show any decelerations or would show a typical pattern of fetal heart rate variability and accelerations.

 

Option D. Deceleration followed by acceleration: This pattern would indicate a combination of deceleration and acceleration, which is not specified here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Decelerations on a Cardio-Tocography indicate a decrease in fetal heart rate by at least 15 bpm lasting for at least 15 seconds, with different types signifying various conditions and levels of concern.

 

Ref: Page no 994, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: The most specific and typical sign of juvenile dermatomyositis in a 17-year-old patient is?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Gottron's papules

 

  • Gottron's papules are a characteristic and specific sign seen in juvenile dermatomyositis.
  • The classical diagnostic criteria for Juvenile Dermatomyositis include the presence of Gottron's papules and heliotrope rash.
  • Gottron's papules are identified as violaceous, lichenoid, inflammatory, flat-topped papules found on the extensor surfaces, particularly the knuckles ( proximal interphalangeal joints, distal interphalangeal joints, and metacarpophalangeal joints) as shown in the image below.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Photosensitive skin rash:

 

  • While photosensitivity can be a feature in some patients with juvenile dermatomyositis, it is not the most specific sign.
  • Photosensitive rashes are also common in other conditions like systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) making it less specific to juvenile dermatomyositis.

 

Option B. Nail bed capillary changes:

 

  • Nail bed capillary changes, such as dilated or drop-out capillaries, can be seen in juvenile dermatomyositis as shown in the image below

 

 

  • However, these changes are also found in other connective tissue diseases, so they are not the most specific for juvenile dermatomyositis.

 

Option D. Malar rash:

 

  • A malar rash, or "butterfly rash" as shown in the image below is typically associated with SLE, not juvenile dermatomyositis.

 

 

  • Although skin manifestations can overlap between different connective tissue diseases, a malar rash is not specific to juvenile dermatomyositis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gottron's papules are flat-topped, red or violaceous papules. They are considered pathognomonic (specifically indicative) of dermatomyositis and are one of the hallmark features of the disease and represent the most specific sign of juvenile dermatomyositis in a 17-year-old patient.

 

Ref - Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition Chapter 53, page nos. 53.4, 53.11

Nelson textbook of pediatrics 21st edition Page no 1182, 1183

choices.text: A patient with sickle cell disease
A patient with recurrent otitis media

questions.text: A new vaccine has been developed to target the 23 serotypes of Streptococcus pneumoniae. This polysaccharide vaccine promises to reduce the morbidity and mortality associated with pneumococcal infections, particularly in certain high-risk groups. Which of the following patient groups would most likely derive the most benefit from this vaccine? [AIIMS NOV 2019]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) A patient with sickle cell disease 

 

  • The polysaccharide vaccine targeting Streptococcus pneumoniae (PPSV-23) provides the greatest advantages to individuals with sickle cell disease.
  • Streptococcus pneumoniae is a bacteria enveloped in a protective layer that the spleen recognizes and eliminates.
  • However, in the case of sickle cell disease, the distorted shape of red blood cells obstructs the spleen's blood vessels, leading to damage.
  • This compromised spleen function, known as hyposplenism, raises the susceptibility to pneumococcal infections.
  • Consequently, sickle cell patients receive the pneumococcal vaccine (PPSV-23) as a preventive measure, aimed at diminishing this vulnerability.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. A child < 2 years: Polysaccharide vaccines are not effective in children under 2 years old due to their immature immune systems. Conjugate vaccines are preferred for this age group.

 

Option C. A patient with cystic fibrosis: While at risk for lung infections, cystic fibrosis patients benefit more from vaccines targeting typical respiratory pathogens, and their spleen function is usually normal.

 

Option D. A patient with recurrent otitis media: This condition is typically managed with other interventions, and the need for a polysaccharide vaccine is less critical.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The PPSV-23 vaccine is most beneficial for patients with sickle cell disease due to their increased susceptibility to pneumococcal infections caused by compromised spleen function.

choices.text: 15 follicular cell clusters contain 10-12 cells
10 follicular cell clusters contain 6-8 cells
3 follicular cell clusters contain 10-15 cells
6 follicular cell clusters contain 10-15 cells

questions.text: The most appropriate biopsy specimen in case of a thyroid biopsy is? (AIIMS NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 6 follicular cell clusters contain 10-15 cells

 

For a thyroid biopsy, particularly when using fine-needle aspiration (FNA), the adequacy of the sample is crucial for accurate diagnosis. The adequacy is determined by the number of follicular cell clusters present and the number of cells within those clusters.

 

The most appropriate specimen should have at least 6 follicular cell clusters, each containing 10-15 cells. This ensures that there is sufficient cellular material for a definitive cytological diagnosis, whether for assessing benign conditions like colloid nodules or diagnosing neoplasms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The following cytologic findings have been used to define specimen adequacy:

questions.text: A patient with diabetes and COPD developed post-operative urinary retention. Which of the following drugs can be used for short-term treatment of the condition? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Bethanechol

 

Bethanechol is a muscarinic agonist that stimulates the bladder's detrusor muscle to contract, thereby promoting urination. It is specifically used in the treatment of post-operative urinary retention. However, caution is required when prescribing bethanechol to patients with COPD or asthma due to its potential to cause bronchoconstriction through its action on M3 receptors in the bronchus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tamsulosin: Tamsulosin is an alpha-1 adrenergic blocker primarily used to treat urinary symptoms associated with benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH). It is not used for post-operative urinary retention.

 

Option C. Terazosin: Terazosin is another alpha-1 adrenergic blocker used for BPH and hypertension. It does not have a role in treating post-operative urinary retention.

 

Option D. Methacholine: Methacholine is a muscarinic receptor agonist used in the diagnosis of asthma by performing the bronchial challenge test. It is not used for treating post-operative urinary retention and can precipitate bronchoconstriction, making it unsuitable for patients with COPD.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bethanechol is used for the short-term treatment of post-operative urinary retention by stimulating the bladder's detrusor muscle. Despite its potential to cause bronchoconstriction in patients with COPD, it is the only suitable drug among the given options for this condition.

questions.text: A 34-year-old orthopedic surgeon is performing a tibial fracture fixation using open reduction and internal fixation (ORIF). During the procedure, the surgeon asks the assistant to identify the correct instrument to hold the bone fragments securely while positioning a metal plate for fixation. The instrument tray contains multiple tools, including bone nibblers, bone cutters, bone plate holding forceps, and bone-holding forceps. Which of the following instruments is the correct choice to stabilize the bone fragments?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Instrument 4

 

Explanation:

 

Bone-holding forceps (Instrument 4) are essential tools in orthopedic surgeries for securing bone fragments during procedures like fracture fixation. They are specifically designed with strong jaws and a locking mechanism to hold the bone fragments firmly, allowing the surgeon to manipulate and align the bones accurately during surgical intervention.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A) Instrument 1 (Bone Cutter):
 Bone cutters are used to remove small bone segments or trim edges during surgery. They have sharp blades for cutting through bone but are not suitable for holding bone fragments in place during fixation.

 

Option B) Instrument 2 (Bone Nibbler):
Bone nibblers are designed to trim and shape bone edges by "nibbling" away small pieces. They help contour the bone but do not provide stabilization needed for holding bone fragments together.

 

Option C) Instrument 3 (Bone Plate Holding Forceps):
Bone plate holding forceps are specifically used to hold a bone plate against the bone during the fixation process, maintaining the plate's position as screws are placed. While useful for plate positioning, they do not hold bone fragments directly and are not substitutes for bone-holding forceps.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Bone-holding forceps are specifically designed for stabilizing bone fragments, ensuring proper alignment during surgical fixation, and contributing to optimal surgical outcomes.

questions.text: A female patient presents to you with a unilateral headache. It is associated with nausea, photophobia, and phonophobia. What is the best drug for acute management? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Sumatriptan

 

The patient's symptoms are characteristic of a migraine, which is often associated with unilateral headache, nausea, photophobia (sensitivity to light), and phonophobia (sensitivity to sound).

 

Sumatriptan: This medication is a serotonin receptor agonist (triptan) used for the acute treatment of migraine attacks. It works by stimulating serotonin (5-HT) receptors in the brain, leading to vasoconstriction of dilated blood vessels and relief from migraine symptoms.

 

The best drug for acute management of a migraine attack in this scenario is Sumatriptan.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Flunarizine: This is a calcium channel blocker used for the prophylactic treatment of migraine, not for acute management.

 

Option C. Propranolol: This beta-blocker is also used for migraine prophylaxis, not for acute attacks.

 

Option D. Topiramate: Used for preventing migraine, not for treating an acute attack.

 

Educaitonal Objective:

 

Sumatriptan is the best medication for the acute management of migraine, characterized by unilateral headache, nausea, photophobia, and phonophobia.

questions.text: SA node release following in response to increasing blood pressure:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Acetylcholine

 

Explanation

 

When blood pressure increases, baroreceptors (pressure-sensitive receptors located in the carotid sinus and aortic arch) are activated. These receptors detect the rise in blood pressure and send signals to the cardiovascular center in the medulla oblongata, specifically to the cardio-inhibitory center (CIC). Activation of the CIC results in the stimulation of the vagus nerve, which releases acetylcholine at the SA node of the heart. Acetylcholine acts on muscarinic receptors to decrease the heart rate (a process known as bradycardia), helping to lower the blood pressure back to normal levels.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Norepinephrine: Norepinephrine is typically released in response to a decrease in blood pressure, not an increase. It is a sympathetic neurotransmitter that increases heart rate and contractility, which would raise blood pressure, not lower it.

 

Option B. Epinephrine: Similar to norepinephrine, epinephrine is released by the adrenal medulla in response to stress or low blood pressure.
